references: To remedy this, we compare local update algorithms on the basis of both convergence and accuracy. Instead of fixing Î³ğ›¾\gamma and Î˜Î˜\Theta, we analyze LocalUpdate as Î³ğ›¾\gamma and Kâ€‹(Î˜)ğ¾Î˜K(\Theta) vary. To do so, we use our theory from Section 4. Values of ÏğœŒ\rho when ServerOpt is gradient descent are given in Table 2. For Î˜=Î˜1:KÎ˜subscriptÎ˜:1ğ¾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K} or Î˜KsubscriptÎ˜ğ¾\Theta_{K}, we define the suboptimality Î”â€‹(Î±,Î³,Î˜)Î”ğ›¼ğ›¾Î˜\Delta(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) by

As shown empirically by Hsu etÂ al. (2019) and as reflected in Table 2, server momentum can improve convergence. To understand this, in Figure 2 we compare Pareto frontiers where Î˜=Î˜1:KÎ˜subscriptÎ˜:1ğ¾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K} and ServerOpt is gradient descent with various types of momentum (Nesterov, heavy-ball, or no momentum). We see a strict ordering of the server optimization methods. Heavy-ball momentum is better than Nesterov momentum, which is better than no momentum.

By Lemma 1, ÏğœŒ\rho and Î”Î”\Delta are still well-defined for Î˜KsubscriptÎ˜ğ¾\Theta_{K} when (Kâ€‹L+Î±)âˆ’1â‰¤Î³<(L+Î±)âˆ’1superscriptğ¾ğ¿ğ›¼1ğ›¾superscriptğ¿ğ›¼1(KL+\alpha)^{-1}\leq\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1}.
To understand what happens in this regime, we generate random symmetric Aâˆˆâ„dÃ—dğ´superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘‘A\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} satisfying cond(A)=L/Î¼condğ´ğ¿ğœ‡\operatorname*{cond}(A)=L/\mu and compute Qâ€‹(Î±,Î³,Î˜K)ğ‘„ğ›¼ğ›¾subscriptÎ˜ğ¾Q(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K}) as in (6). We then compute Îºğœ…\kappa via (9), and plug this into Table 2 and (17) to get Ï,Î”ğœŒÎ”\rho,\Delta. This gives us a simulated Pareto frontier for Î˜KsubscriptÎ˜ğ¾\Theta_{K}, which we compare to Î˜1:KsubscriptÎ˜:1ğ¾\Theta_{1:K} in Figure 5. For details and additional experiments, see Appendix D.1.

In order to plot Pareto frontiers for MAML-style methods (Î˜=Î˜KÎ˜subscriptÎ˜ğ¾\Theta=\Theta_{K}) when Î³>(Kâ€‹L+Î±)âˆ’1ğ›¾superscriptğ¾ğ¿ğ›¼1\gamma>(KL+\alpha)^{-1}, we generate random symmetric matrices Aâˆˆâ„dÃ—dğ´superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘‘A\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} satisfying Î¼â€‹Iâª¯Aâª¯Lâ€‹Iprecedes-or-equalsğœ‡ğ¼ğ´precedes-or-equalsğ¿ğ¼\mu I\preceq A\preceq LI. We then compute the associated matrix Qâ€‹(Î±,Î³,Î˜K)ğ‘„ğ›¼ğ›¾subscriptÎ˜ğ¾Q(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K}). Once we have these matrices, we can compute the condition number Îºğœ…\kappa of Qâ€‹(Î±,Î³,Î˜K)â€‹Ağ‘„ğ›¼ğ›¾subscriptÎ˜ğ¾ğ´Q(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K})A. We can then compute Ï,Î”ğœŒÎ”\rho,\Delta by substituting Îºğœ…\kappa into Table 2 and Lemma 5.

In short, we see clear evidence that the choice of client learning rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma leads to a trade-off between convergence and accuracy. However, as shown in Lemmas 3 and 4, the condition number of the surrogate loss changes depending on parameters such as Î³ğ›¾\gamma. To derive asymptotically optimal rates for strongly convex functions (such as the ones in Table 2), one must generally set the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta according to the condition number. Thus, we repeat the experiments in Figure 12, but where we tune the server learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta instead of fixing it. This helps account for how the optimization dynamics can change as a function of the client learning rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma. We vary the server learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta over

and select Î·ğœ‚\eta that leads to the smallest average training loss over the last 100 rounds. The result is given in Figure 13. Again, we see similar behavior, but see that when the server learning rate is tuned, larger client learning rates may do much better initially. This reflects the fact that in Table 2, the best convergence rates can only be obtained by setting parameters of ServerOpt correctly.

Dataset Train Clients Train Examples Test Clients Test Examples

CIFAR-100 500 50,000 100 10,000
Shakespeare 715 16,068 715 2,356
references: We use three datasets: the federated extended MNIST dataset (FEMNIST)Â (Caldas etÂ al., 2018), CIFAR-100Â (Krizhevsky and Hinton, 2009), and ShakespeareÂ (Caldas etÂ al., 2018). The first two are image datasets, and the third is a language dataset. All datasets are publicly available. We specifically use the versions available in TensorFlow FederatedÂ (Ingerman and Ostrowski, 2019), which gives a federated structure to all three. We keep the client partitioning when training, and create a test dataset by taking a union over all test client datasets. Statistics on the number of clients and examples in each dataset are given in Table 3.
